Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships to Support STEM majors Computational Sciences Minors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will award scholarships to academically talented Biology, Chemistry, and Physics majors interested in careers and graduate education, who also demonstrate financial need. The scholarship recipients will form a cohort of students who undertake pursuit of a Computational Science minor that will expose them to computational techniques relevant to their major field of study. New and existing support structures will be used to ensure the success of each scholar. Key academic features of this project will include opportunities for participation in undergraduate research, conference presentations and/or publications on this research, and a senior capstone interdisciplinary project in computational science. Talented STEM graduates with a background in computational sciences will help U.S. industries by contributing to a workforce able to compete and innovate in a global economy.

Research has shown that a computational science curriculum can benefit STEM students in a variety of ways including (a) expanding employment options for those who enter college loving science without knowing how they will use the degree when they graduate, (b) providing them with a compelling context in which to learn mathematical and computing concepts thereby, aiding retention, and (c) requiring them to work in interdisciplinary teams and subsequently learn how to communicate science more effectively. Formative and summative evaluation will consist of comparisons of S-STEM participant retention rates and satisfaction with students in the STEM Honors Program and the general STEM population at PLNU. Dissemination of the results of evaluation and information about the project in general, will be done through a website and national meetings sponsored by the Special Interest Group for Computer Science Education or the Society of Industrial and Applied Mathematics. The work will also be presented at Joint Mathematics Meetings (attended by special interest groups on mathematics in industry and mathematical biology). The results will be submitted to disciplinary educational journals such as PRIMUS: Problems, Resources, and Issues in Mathematics Undergraduate Studies, The Journal of Chemical Education, and Physical Review Special Topics - Physics Education Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Objectives:

From 2016-2021, the Scholarships to Support STEM majors Computational Sciences Minors (S-STEM-CS) program at Point Loma Nazarene University sought to improve recruitment and retention of high financial need students into our STEM programs by providing $10,000 scholarships to academically-talented and financially-needy students majoring in a STEM discipline and minoring in Computational Science. Scholars were required to commit to completing a minor in Computational Science at the time of the award (though once awarded, they could maintain the scholarship even if they dropped the minor). This functioned to generate a natural cohort of students in the same CS classes, despite otherwise being spread out among different STEM majors; it also guaranteed them a common CS faculty advisor in addition to their major advisor. Scholars were also guaranteed spots in our selective summer research program.

Activities:

In accordance with our goals, we selected 14 original S-STEM-CS scholars in two cohorts of 7, each including 4 incoming freshmen and 3 additional rising sophomores. The second path into the cohort was proposed to allow students (especially first generation or under-represented minority students) who might need additional exposure to computational science prior to applying for the scholarship.

Adjustments to our budget (due to excess scholarship funds obtained by one scholar and reduced travel and research supply spending due to COVID), twice led us to reallocate funds (in 2019 and again in 2020) to award 10 additional one-year S-STEM-CS scholarships (in amounts varying from $3,000-$10,000), bringing the total number of scholars to 24.

Outcomes:

All 24 of the S-STEM-CS scholars graduated with STEM majors at PLNU. 13 of the 14 traditionally-selected scholars (the ones who committed to the minor) completed the computational science minor, along with 4 of the 10 one-year scholars. 12 of the original 14 scholars (and 7 of the 10 one-year scholars) participated in summer research at PLNU.

Of the 24 scholars, all but three reported continuing in STEM in some fashion. Four are currently enrolled in PhD programs in STEM (one in biology, one in biological chemistry, one in physics, and one in computer science), and one in a master’s degree program (in machine learning). Three are enrolled in or applying to medical school (with one participating in medical research in the summer). One is enrolled in veterinary school. One is pursing graduate studies in Business Intelligence & Analytics, with an emphasis in data science. One is teaching high school math and computer science. Seventeen are currently employed in STEM fields (e.g. doing COVID wastewater testing, ecosystem studies, programming, or oligonucleotide synthesis), four of whom have expressed an interest in graduate studies in STEM in the future.

Conclusions:

Overall, the S-STEM-CS scholarship program allowed us to recruit and retain excellent students in STEM at PLNU, many of whom would have been unlikely to be able to afford to enroll and/or remain at PLNU without the scholarship. For the original scholars, the scholarship appeared to be a motivating factor in their decision to pursue a computational science minor, yet these students reported a high level of satisfaction with the coursework, cohort-building, and enrichment opportunities afforded by the S-STEM-CS scholarship.
